Type of loss: Crops, Food stocks, Agricultural infrastructure, Livestock production
text: The disaster impacted critical infrastructure and led to extensive loss of livelihoods: losses and damage to crops, food stocks, agricultural infrastructure and assets, and livestock production are estimated at USD 6.4 billion.nTwo months after the disaster, the combined effects of the destruction of workplaces, interruption of economic activities, loss of life, injuries, and internal displacement has still severely compromised the ability of households to meet their basic needs.
Over a third of the key informants reported damage to community-level agricultural structures and up to 80 percent reported damage to agricultural equipment in their village.
Over a third of the key informants reported damage to community-level agricultural structures and up to 80 percent reported damage to agricultural equipment in their village.

For example, agricultural infrastructure, including warehouses, packaging and storage facilities, as well as equipment, have been severely damaged; more than 13 284 livestock shelters were destroyed and around 815 000 heads of livestock were lost; fisheries were impacted; and markets and supply chains were disrupted.

For example, agricultural infrastructure, including warehouses, packaging and storage facilities, as well as equipment, have been severely damaged; more than 13 284 livestock shelters were destroyed and around 815 000 heads of livestock were lost; fisheries were impacted; and markets and supply chains were disrupted.

Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) also stated that more than 20 percent of Turkey's food production was damaged in the earthquake, which affected 11 important agricultural provinces.
FAO pointed out that the earthquake-affected region of Turkey, known as fertile lands, constitutes about 15 percent of the country's agricultural income.

Más del 20 % de la producción agrícola de Türkiye está dañada En Türkiye, el terremoto afectó gravemente a 11 provincias agrícolas clave y a 15,73 millones de personas y más del 20 % de la producción alimentaria del país.

Las evaluaciones iniciales indican importantes repercusiones en la agricultura, con estimaciones preliminares de 1 300 millones de USD en daños y 5 100 millones de USD en pérdidas para el sector.

La producción pesquera también se ha visto comprometida debido a las repercusiones en 34 granjas piscícolas y tres puertos pesqueros y la pérdida de especies de peces fundamentales.

Type of loss: Crops, Livestock, Food Stocks and Agricultural Infrastructure and Assets
text: The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) reported that the earthquakes caused $6.7 billion in losses and damage to crops, livestock, food stocks and agricultural infrastructure and assets5.
The earthquake-affected region is known as Türkiye's "fertile crescent" and accounts for almost 15 percent of the country's agricultural income.

Meanwhile, the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) said on Friday that more than 20 per cent of Türkiye's food production has been damaged by the earthquake, which impacted 11 key agricultural provinces.

Meanwhile, the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) said on Friday that more than 20 per cent of Türkiye's food production has been damaged by the earthquake, which impacted 11 key agricultural provinces.
Initial assessments indicate significant impacts to agriculture, with preliminary estimates of $1.3 billion in damage and $5.1 billion in losses to the sector.
Fish production has also been compromised, with 34 fish farms and three fishing ports impacted and the loss of key fish species.
Initial assessments indicate significant impacts to agriculture, with preliminary estimates of $1.3 billion in damage and $5.1 billion in losses to the sector.
Fish production has also been compromised, with 34 fish farms and three fishing ports impacted and the loss of key fish species.

More than 20 percent of Türkiye’s agricultural production damaged In Türkiye, the earthquake severely impacted 11 key agricultural provinces a­ffecting 15.73 million people and more than 20 percent of the country's food production.

In terms of losses, the agriculture sector incurred the heaviest toll with the gap in access to food estimated at US$1.3 billion (83% of total losses).

The governorate of Aleppo suffered the greatest damages (44% of total damages, predominantly in housing then agriculture), followed by Idlib (21%).
